greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: The least missing digit in the primorial base expansion of n. Only significant digits are considered, as the leading zeros are ignored.
comment: For n = 0 the value is ambiguous, thus the sequence starts from n=1.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..32768
Index entries for sequences related to primorial base
example: 19 in primorial base (A049345) is written as "301". The least missing digit is 2, thus a(19) = 2.
program: (PARI) A329027(n) = { my(m=Map(), p=2); while(n, mapput(m,(n%p),1); n = n\p; p = nextprime(1+p)); for(k=0,oo,if(!mapisdefined(m,k),return(k))); };
xref: Cf. A328574 (after its initial term, gives the positions of zeros in this sequence), A328840 (after its initial term, gives the positions of ones in this sequence).
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Nov 03 2019
